reference.shortdesc: Included content is a reference to non-DITA content outside the current document that will be rendered at the location of the reference. The resource is specified using either a URI or a key reference. Processing expectations for the referenced data can also be specified.

section.title: Usage information
section.p: The include element is intended as a specialization base and for the following use cases:

ul.li: The transclusion of non-DITA XML within foreign element using parse="xml"
The transclusion of preformatted textual content within pre element using parse="text"
The transclusion of plain-text prose within DITA elements using parse="text"

section.p: For example, the include element can be specialized to an element such as coderef as a way to include preformatted sample programming code.
The include element is not intended to reference DITA content. Use conref or conkeyref to reuse DITA content.

section.title: Processing expectations
section.p: The include element instructs processors to insert the contents of the referenced resource at the location of the include element. If the content is unavailable to the processor or cannot be processed using the specified parse value, the contents of the fallback element, if any, are presented instead.
Processors SHOULD support the parse values text and xml.
Processors SHOULD detect the encoding of the referenced document based on the rules described for the encoding attribute.

section.title: Attributes
section.p: The following attributes are available on this element: , , , and keyref.

example.title: Examples
example.p: For the most part, include is intended to be used as a basis for specialization. The following examples use it directly for purposes of illustration.

fig.title: Inclusion of XML markup other than SVG or MathML
fig.p: In the following code sample, the include element references a tag library descriptor file:
fig.codeblock: <fig> <title>JSP Tag Library Elements and Attributes</title> <foreign outputclass="tld"> <include href="../src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/jsp-tag-library.tld" parse="xml" format="tld"/> </foreign> </fig>

fig.title: Inclusion of README text into a DITA topic, with fallback
fig.p: In the following code sample, a README text file is referenced in order to reuse a list of changes to a set of source code:
fig.codeblock: <topic id="readme"> <title>Summary of changes</title> <shortdesc>This topic describes changes in the project source code.</shortdesc> <body> <include href="../src/README.txt" parse="text" encoding="UTF-8"> <fallback>See README.txt in the source package for a list of changes.</fallback> </include> </body> </topic>
